_header: See much say little and learn to suffer in time
Note:
Cf. Brown (1939)
XBrown, Carleton Fairchild. “See Myche, Say Lytell, and Lerne to Saffer in Tyme.” Modern Language Notes 54 (1939): 131-3, 131-3.
Bibliographic Ghosts: London, Victoria and Albert Museum, National Art Library Dyce 34 (Dyce’s transcript of STC 17026)
_description: Proverbs ascribed to R. Stokys (by MacCracken to Lydgate) — five stanzas rhyme royal

OxfCCC203.First Lines:
Se meche sey lytyll and lerne to suffre in tymeEnprinte these thre
                    in thy remembrance…
OxfCCC203.Last Lines:
…Where fore thy selfe and thou wylte kepe fro crim[
                    edge]Se meche say lytill and lerne to suffre in tyme

BLAdd29729.First Lines:
See myche say lytell & lerne to soffar in tymeemprynte thes
                    thre in thy remembraunce…
BLAdd29729.Last Lines:
…wherfore thy self and thow wolt kepe fro crymese myche sa
                    lytell and lerne to suffar in tyme
BLAdd29729.Note:
Ends ‘Explicit lidgat’ (f. 130v) all by scribe
                    (John Stow).
BLAdd29729.Editions:
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems.
EETS
         o.s. 192 (1934); repr. 1961: 2.800-1.

BLRoy2D.xxxvii.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild,
                        ed.  
             Religious Lyrics of the XVth Century.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1939: 279-80.

NLS1931.First Lines:
Se myche say lytell and lerne to suffyr in tymeEnprint these iii
                    wyll in thi remembraunce…
NLS1931.Last Lines:
…Wherfore wyse caton saythe to olde and yongeThe fyrst cheyf
                    vertue is to kekepe owre tonge
NLS1931.Note:
Stanza 1 only, immediately follows first stanza of 1108 as if part of same work, and
                    immediately followed by 4811 as
                    if same work.
NLS1931.Facsimiles:
Hardman,  Phillipa. 
             The Heege Manuscript: A Facsimile of National Library of Scotland MS
                Advocates 19.3.1.
         Leeds Texts and Monographs, n.s. 16. Leeds: School of English,
            2000.
